comments.commentBody: The more nonsensical the cover-up, the more serious the lie. It's obvious to anyone with eyes that Trump and associates are covering up something so wrong, so dirty, that they're twisting themselves in knots to hide it. Just like during the campaign Trump could not keep his mouth shut about Putin and other clues to his dirty dealings. This is a stinking business, and all the cries of witch hunts by Trump and the Russians will not end the investigation. Our fragile democracy is being seriously challenged and we must do everything we can to protect it. We must start with the truth.
Congress better move quickly to impeach before our military are forced to coup.

Its time to sue for a release of Trumps tax returns.

If Trump could get a president to turn over his birth certificate, the citizenry and Congress should be able to get this prez. to release his tax returns.

Quid pro quo.

If Trump can't prove he's not beholden to Russians, either thru the govt or organized crime,or other nefarious actors -then the the accusations are true. Much like Trump and the Alt-right, and the Alex Jones's and other conspiracy nut-jobs claimed Obama was not a citizen (even after the BC was released) - then until Trump can prove no financial ties to Russia, the gov't or its officials the accusations are all true. And impeachment proceedings should begin.

Quid pro quo, Mr. quasi-Prez. Prove something tangible, your word is no good.

For a Saturday, this puzzle seemed queasy (quick and easy), even though I didn't know TAYLORSCHILLING, SPORCLE, NEUER, ARIE, NHRA, LEIGH, or TAGS (just kidding on that last one). I just HACKed my way though it. It had spark, that indefinable quality that some puzzles have and other don't. I loved all the longs except TAYLORSCHILLING, and they were the anchors that kept the joy spread throughout.

No big NITS. Just played it LOOS, kept my focus INTHECROSSHAIRS, and nothings seemed to go ARIE. Loved it. THATSIT.

I understand why the authors of the article included a reference to the newly circulated a picture of Sen. Schumer and Mr. Putin--complete disclosure-- that is making the rounds of the alt-right, but it should have been identified the photo as having been taken over 10 years ago, and stated the context.  Let's don't start with the "false equivalency" fantasy that skewed reporting of the campaign.

In his twits, Trump seems to say a judge turned down the first FISA order.  I can appreciate that judge might need more evidence before they agreed this Prism pull back was warranted.  Had Trump known, he'd have blown the cover to the Russians.

IF the DNC can be hacked, why isn't there some clever 9th-grader available to get Trump's tax returns?

Is he hiding something, or just being a brat because he can?
I remember the NATICK puzzle well, because I actually knew NC WYETH.  I have no idea what the initials stand for!
Yup, and Trump seems to understand the judge demanded more evidence, and then granted the FISA order.

The story about your parents is beautiful, particularly how "their beloved cat" helped your father cope with your mother's passing.  As a cat person, I don't know what I would do without the love of my felines in good and bad times.

Why was Trump's fawning over Putin so publicly effusive from the get go? If his objective, all along, was to achieve a rapprochement with Russia, i.e.the lifting of sanctions, would it not have served him better to be discreet about his Russia policy intentions? Why telegraph, over and over again?   Apart from praising the Russian president at every opportunity, he brazenly appealed for his help hacking Hillary Clinton's emails. Is it because he believed he would not win and ingratiating himself with Putin assured him of the future business with Russia that had until now eluded him?

There's an apt saying to apply:
If you can't stand the heat, stay out of the kitchen.
Trump surely did not do his homework (in more than one area) in his pursuit of the Presidency. Get used to the heat Mr. President. It comes with the job.

We forget that the US, the DNC, and the entire world expected Hillary to win the election. It makes sense Russia would hack Hillarys campaign to mess with the incoming president, not elect Trump instead. But no one has bothered to Consider this point in the press. If this massive effort to Lynch Trump were put into fixing Health care, infrastructure, job creation, and national debt, the things Americans REALLY care about, we might be well along the way to a better America. Instead, our bipartisan politicians are doing what they do best. In the name of protecting our Democracy, they are destroying our future and fighting like teenagers, ... again. When will they all grow up and actually Serve the People?
THAT was a brilliant summary of the situation.

No one "wins" in war. No one. The Robber Barons might get more money and what they consider "power" but they die, too. Alone. With nothing. Just as they came into the world. Just like every other human being.

The only thing that will save humanity is a collective consciousness of cooperation, moral-ethical-social conscience and living by the Golden Rule:
"Do Unto Others As You Would Have Others Do Unto You."

That is not a "christian" or other religious idea. It is an idea for the humanity in us.

This always reminds me of the best of us:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/We_Are_the_World

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9AjkUyX0rVw

The key to this whole mess may lie within Mr. Trump's tax return. In response, I will be sure to attend the related April 15th, Tax Day protest and demand Mr. Trump adhere to a fiffty year presidential practice by releasing his tax returns. What does he have to hide?

Does it mean that any mechanism to defeat NSA's attempt to collect citizen's private data is illegal? I hope not.  When law enforcement conducts a undercover operation that misrepresent themselves, it is only fair that citizens may take counter measures.
After all, businesses are people, too. Right, Spade?

It's always fascinating to observe the change in people when it's their ox getting gored instead of the other guy's.  Those loving the technological takeover of practices, policies and indeed, minds, blanche when it be becomes apparent that their sinecure is next for scheduled disruption.  Today, it's closed-shop medallion cabs.  Tomorrow, long-haul trucking.  Soon, attorneys, professors, office managers and diagnosticians will be superfluous in the human sense.  What will all these graduates of Western NE Law school and instructors in unnecessary and not-career-track college courses, like "fill-in-the-blank studies" do?  No tenure, no pensions, no need for their by now anachronistic skills.  Perhaps Uber will hire them assuming they pass the background tests.  Until of course, the service goes driverless.  Happy now all you futurists?

How is it leveling the playing field by removing regulations? Taxi companies have far more onerous rules they have to follow. As long as Uber doesn't have to follow these regulations, I find the current situation very unfair to Taxi companies.

That and I don't trust uber one bit. If they are geofencing enforcement officials, what are they doing with my own personal location data?

#deleteuber

Laws and regulations of taxis grew over time as they became necessary for public health and safety or beneficial as workplce protection for taxi drivers. Yes, uber and many others discovered the libertarian fact that if no protections, costs go down. Do we want raw capitalism and its cruel deadly society, or do we want regulated capitalism, and a healthy cooperative society? The choice should be easy. We don't need a reset to raw to begin the long process of regulating all over again, do we?
Nothing to do with "public health and safety"; just monopolistic taxi medallion systems and campaign contributions.

The article is written as a slam afainst uber but their tactics make me revere the company even more
Good for them for resisting the ridiculous heavy handed keystone cops
Leave uber aline and stip wasting tax dollars
Transportation has improved exponentially in areas rhat uber serves
To hell with the corrupt dirty inefficient taxis and the publicnofficials they bribe ti engage in these investigations

This article provides an excellent example for the 'new face of profiling'. That is, a computer ap that reflects a psychological, social, political, economic or other agenda based upon the travel habits of its users. Any profile it uses, of course, is biased by the beliefs of its programmers.

One reason the the regulation of cab service is to provide universal access by all users. Everybody is welcome. Under the new face of profiling, the things you believe in will dictate the kind of service you will receive.

And the cab drivers themselves will probably not be immune. Imagine the response by the company to drivers who attend a meeting at the Union Hall, or accepted a fare from someone who is likely an ACLU member.

Uber is the worst kind of Wild West capitalism. And it represents the most retrograde component of transportation in cities. In New York City, with at least 13,000 yellow cabs and uncounted green outer borough taxis, and gypsy cars, dollar vans, legitimate black cars, and a vast subway and bus system, Uber is the last thing we needed.
Uber's contribution to pollution, noise, congestion and lost travel time is devastating. They are estimated to have 49,000 cars on our streets. That's triple the number of yellow cabs. And the drivers are downing in bankruptcy as they end up with penny wages, huge vehicle loans, and long hours.
Uber is a vile parasite. And Mayor DiBlasio surrendered like a whimpering child to their conquest of our streets.

Since you are speaking from and for the Right, it appears, why are illegal actions described in the article not treated as needing punishment by the forces of law and order.  Is it that all laws can be broken or avoided if done in search of profit?  Outside of Manhattan a phone call to a service usually provides local transportation, local service can also be found at commuter train stations throughout the US.  But I guess that an international company with a cool app is much better and worthy of use and support regardless of their practices.  Uber keeps profiles on customers and associated contacts but refuses to fully look into driver backgrounds.  Sad

If Uber actually "cared" about filling a market niche for on-demand car rides, they would have created an app that connects riders to drivers without being the middleman. Such a service could have worked if the drivers were charged a monthly fee to have a listing. Then all they created was a service and how people use it is not on them. Instead, they created a business model in which they are the gatekeepers between the driver with the car and the rider customer. Yet they want none of the responsibility that comes with that position, but ALL of the profits. Uber is a reflection of the person who created it, zero integrity and zero respect for laws. I personally do not do business with companies and people of this ilk. #deleteuber
